questions.neutral: Did you make it through the day?

hobby.message: Still flying like no one's watching?
Urban exploration or just drinking underground?
Political literature or political theater tonight?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect political literature. It's a reminder of what was lost.
neutral_answer: Yes, I did. Nothing much changes, just routines going sideways lately.
Spent some hours with old books. My hobby is collecting and restoring them.
Not easy, with the city’s mood and all these tribunals flaring up.
Strange times for everyone, I suppose.
I made it through. Can’t say it’s ever dull now.
Restored another old book from my collection tonight. That’s my way to unwind.
Tribunal noise leaking into everything, even private hours.
It’s harder to keep certain habits invisible, with what’s surfaced lately.
I suppose most people wouldn’t bother, but it matters to me.
Made it, just about. I spent the evening repairing a banned book—my usual hobby.
Restoring spines and bindings keeps my mind off today’s chaos.
It’s not exactly encouraged, but I’ve collected these forbidden texts for years.
The latest tribunal distracted even my steady hands. Hard to focus with so much coming undone.
Seems every story out there now echoes inside my little library.
Still, I finished Kherov’s volume, despite it all.
Made it through, mostly thanks to my little ritual: book restoration.
I collect and repair political literature they tried to erase. Banned texts, mostly.
Every session at the tribunal rattles the city—old secrets feel closer to the surface.
Tonight I stitched a volume by candlelight, with half the vanished reappearing in my mind.
When I started, it was rebellion. Now it’s almost protection, or memory work.
Some pages came loose from the glue—fitting, with all these revelations breaking free.
Funny, felt like I was fixing history while everything else fell apart.
Barely. The city’s nervous energy makes the walls thinner, even in rooms full of books.
I restore banned political works—Kherov, Braga, the ones that aren’t meant to survive.
Every session at the tribunal, I hear fragments that match words in my library.
Used to do it for quiet rebellion, late at night under watchlist pressure.
Now, with the vanished reappearing, my hobby’s less secret, more fragile. Layers of memory exposed.
Tonight I re-stitched a volume I hid years ago, hearing testimonies echo in my head.
Old pages, newsprint, typeset margins—all telling stories no system can fully erase.
Feels like I protect the city’s forgotten heart, even when my own score drops ever lower.
hobby_answer: Books outlast policy. Old habits die hard.
Restoration these days is a private thing, if it happens at all.
Harder to keep collections safe since the BCI failures.
Most just want spectacle; I prefer a well-bound argument.
Recent chaos makes subtlety all the more essential.
Yes, they do. Most leaders fade; ideas persist on paper.
I restore what others erase. Rare editions, commentary, even banned margins.
Lately, everyone wants history for their testimony. My sources get requests.
Public tribunals mean old texts aren't safe at home anymore.
Vanished citizens reappear, hunting for the same forbidden authors.
Hard to know who actually reads, or just wants evidence.
They definitely age better. Irony, isn't it?
My collection covers banned manifestos, hidden Council drafts, anonymous annotations.
Used to restore in silence. Now, neighbors ask for originals after hearings.
Testimonies make everyone nostalgic for old arguments, not just official lines.
During the tribunal, I loaned out three volumes—dangerous, but worth it.
Feels less forbidden now, but more vulnerable too.
Citywide chaos turned preservation into a kind of public service.
Without doubt. Words linger, even after reputations collapse.
I collect political literature to remember how dissent sounds—uncensored.
Binding a damaged volume, tracing margin notes, that's peace for me.
Since the tribunal, strangers come seeking lost histories—old texts are traded openly.
One vanished woman returned, recognized a line I restored last winter.
Security’s watching us, but people finally care about forgotten voices.
Restoring isn’t escapism now—more like urgent archiving.
For hours last week, whole blocks debated passages outside my door.
Absolutely. My first banned book outlasted the official who forbade it.
I was twelve when I found a Council-era pamphlet in my father’s attic.
Been restoring, annotating, cataloguing ever since—every regime leaves erasures to fill.
Tribunal changed everything—reading circles spilled onto the streets, texts circulate out of hiding.
Vanished citizens swapped narratives for volumes I’d repaired, sometimes with their own notes.
Texts once hidden in walls now become evidence at hearings.
Spent hours mediating feuds over authorship—words spark old rivalries now.
My rooms aren’t just archives—they’re collaborative memory, risky but alive.
Lately, every page feels like both protest and inheritance.
